title: How to Create a Bode Plot

steps.headline: Check that the function generator and oscilloscope are connected to the closest AC outlet.
Connect the first probe to the “50 Ω OUTPUT” connector on the front lower-right corner of the function generator.
steps.description: a. Connect the red positive lead to the input terminal of your circuit. b. Connect the black negative lead to the ground terminal of your circuit.

steps.headline: Connect the second probe to the “CH 1” connector on the front of the oscilloscope.
steps.description: a. Connect the red positive lead to the input terminal of your circuit. b. Connect the black negative lead to the ground terminal of your circuit.

steps.headline: Connect the third probe to the “CH 2” connector on the front of the oscilloscope.
steps.description: a. Connect the red positive lead to the output terminal of your circuit. b. Connect the black negative lead to the ground terminal of your circuit, (unless instructed otherwise by the lab TA).

steps.headline: Press the power button (labeled “O/I”) on the top side of the oscilloscope.
Press the “POWER” button on the front upper-right corner of the function generator.
After the equipment performs its self-test, it should look similar to what’s shown in Figure 2 (shown in this step).

parts.name: Set the function generator frequency and amplitude

steps.headline: Press the button below “FREQ.” on the function generator.
steps.description: The light above the button turns on. Your screen should look similar to the Figure shown in this step.

steps.headline: Adjust the frequency to the lowest frequency you wish to test, your starting frequency.
steps.description: This can be done with the large dial on the function generator, or with the four soft-keys below the display. The buttons marked “- val +” change the digit under the cursor, and the “< cur >” buttons move the cursor.

steps.headline: Press the button below “AMPL.” on the function generator.
steps.description: The light above the button turns on. Your screen should look similar to Figure 5 now.

steps.headline: Adjust the amplitude to the voltage specified in the lab procedure for the circuit being tested, using the same dial or soft-keys.
steps.description: Notice that this is Vpp, the peak-to-peak voltage. The maximum (positive) and minimum (negative) voltages of the wave will be half the peak-to-peak voltage.

steps.headline: Press the button “OUTPUT” on the function generator.
steps.description: The light to the left of the button turns on.

steps.headline: Press the “DEFAULT SETUP” button on the upper-right corner of the oscilloscope.
steps.description: Its display should look similar to Figure 6. The wave may appear on the display, or it may only show noise. The next steps will bring it into focus.

steps.headline: Press the “AUTOSET” button on the upper-right corner of the oscilloscope.
steps.description: Its display should look similar to Figure 7, and the waves should appear in focus.

steps.headline: Press the second soft-key from the top.
steps.description: This tells the oscilloscope to display a single period of the wave. Your display should look like the one in Figure 7. The oscilloscope soft-keys are located to the right of the display.

steps.headline: Press the “MEASURE” button on the top middle of the oscilloscope.
steps.description: The default measurement screen will be shown, like the one in Figure 8.

steps.headline: Press the top soft-key on the oscilloscope to select the first measurement.
steps.description: Press the top soft-key labeled “Source” until “CH1” is listed. Press the second soft-key from the top labeled “Type” until “Freq” is shown. Your display should look like the one in Figure 9. Press the bottom soft-key to go back.

steps.headline: Press the second soft-key from the top to select the second measurement.
steps.description: Press the top soft-key labeled “Source” until “CH1” is listed. Press the second soft-key from the top labeled “Type” until “Pk-Pk” is shown. Your display should look like the one in Figure 10. Press the bottom soft-key to go back.

steps.headline: Press the third soft-key from the top to select the third measurement.
steps.description: Press the top soft-key labeled “Source” until “CH2” is listed. Press the second soft-key from the top labeled “Type” until “Freq” is shown. Your display should look like the one in Figure 11. Press the last soft-key (fifth from the top) to go back.

steps.headline: Press the fourth soft-key from the top to select the fourth measurement.
steps.description: Press the top soft-key labeled “Source” until “CH2” is listed. Press the second soft-key from the top labeled “Type” until “Pk-Pk” is shown. Your display should look like the one in Figure 12. Press the bottom soft-key to go back.

steps.headline: Turn the “HORIZONTAL SEC/DIV” knob counterclockwise a little until it clicks once.
steps.description: Your display should now show more than one period, like the display in Figure 13. The CH1 and CH2 frequency measurements should change from “?” to the true reading.

steps.headline: Press the “CURSOR” button on the top middle of the oscilloscope.
steps.description: The default screen should look like the one in Figure 14.

steps.headline: Press the top soft-key next to “Type” until “Time” is listed.
steps.description: The middle of the right column of the screen shows us the readings we are interested in:  Δt and ΔV. Below that, the readings for Cursor 1 and Cursor 2 are shown.

parts.name: Creating the worksheet to record your data

steps.headline: On your lab computer, open Excel and start a new spreadsheet.
steps.description: Label the columns “Frequency,” “Vin,” “dV,” “Vout,” “Delay,” “Phase” and “Gain.”

steps.headline: Below “Frequency,” enter each frequency you plan to test (refer to your lab procedures).
Below “Vout” in cell D2, enter this formula:  =B2+C2
Press return.
steps.description: The “=B2+C2” turns into a zero since we haven’t entered anything into B2 or C2.

steps.headline: Press Ctrl+D, then return.
steps.description: The formula gets copied from D2 into D3, with Excel changing its formula into “=B3+C3” automatically. Keep pressing Ctrl+D then return until you fill the column for each of your frequencies.

steps.headline: Below “Phase” in cell F2, enter this formula:  =2*pi()*A2*E2
Press return.
steps.description: Press Ctrl+D, then return as you did before to fill the column.

steps.headline: Below “Gain” in cell G2, enter this formula:  =20*log10(D2/B2)
Press return.
steps.description: Press Ctrl+D, then return as you did before to fill the column. Ignore the errors for now.

steps.headline: Save this worksheet to use as a template.
steps.description: You can use it the next time you need to create a Bode plot, letting you skip Part 6.

parts.name: Getting the data for the Bode plot

steps.headline: Your oscilloscope should still be on the cursor display from the end of Part 5.
steps.description: If it isn’t, press the “CURSOR” button on the top middle of the oscilloscope.

steps.headline: Turn the “HORIZONTAL SEC/DIV” knob to zoom in on the wave, so that a single period is shown.
Push the fourth soft-key from the top to select Cursor 1.
Turn the “multi-function” knob located on the center top of the oscilloscope to move the cursor.
steps.description: The knob is unlabeled and is located just above the “PRINT” button.

steps.headline: Position the cursor so that it lines up with the very top of the CH1 (upper, in orange) wave.
Push the last soft-key (fifth from the top) to select Cursor 2.
Turn the “multi-function” knob located on the center top of the oscilloscope to move the cursor.
steps.description: Position the cursor so that it lines up with the very top of the CH2 (lower, in blue) wave.

steps.headline: On your spreadsheet, record your data:
steps.description: a. Vin – the voltage reading under Cursor 1 (820 mV in the example above; record this as 0.820 in your spreadsheet) b. dV – the reading next to ΔV (20.0 mV in the example above; record this as 0.020 in your spreadsheet) c. Delay – the reading next to Δt (160.0 µs in the example above; record this as 0.000160 in your spreadsheet).

steps.headline: For the Gain plot: Enter one step here and then click 1.
steps.description: Select the Frequency and Gain columns.

steps.headline: Click “Insert” and look for the “Scatter Chart” option.
Right-click the vertical axis and choose “Format Axis…”
Click “Logarithmic scale”
Right-click the horizontal axis and choose “Format Axis…”
Click “Logarithmic scale”
For the Phase plot: Select the Frequency and Gain columns.
Enter one step here and then click “Insert” and look for the “Scatter Chart” option.
Right-click the horizontal axis and choose “Format Axis…”
Click “Logarithmic scale”.

tyn: Oscilloscope (the Tektronix TDS2012b is used here)
Function generator (the Hameg HM8131 is used here)
Three oscilloscope probes (no specific type is called for)
A computer with a spreadsheet program (Microsoft Excel 2013 is used here)
